title: Isaac Humphries
text:
Isaac Bradley Humphries (born 5 January 1998) is an Australian professional <a href="basketball">basketball</a> player for the <a href="Adelaide%2036ers">Adelaide 36ers</a> of the <a href="National%20Basketball%20League%20%28Australia%29">National Basketball League</a> (NBL). He played <a href="college%20basketball">college basketball</a> for the <a href="Kentucky%20Wildcats%20men%27s%20basketball">Kentucky Wildcats</a>.
Early life.
Born in the <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> suburb of <a href="Caringbah">Caringbah</a>, Humphries grew up in <a href="Cronulla">Cronulla</a> and started playing basketball at the age of 12. He had earlier played <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a>. In 2010, he spent six months in <a href="Hamilton%2C%20Ontario">Hamilton, Ontario</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. "I had a pretty big growth spurt when I lived in Canada", he told theleader.com.au in January 2014.
College career.
Humphries attended <a href="Scots%20College%20%28Sydney%29">Scots College</a> in <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> and the <a href="Australian%20Institute%20of%20Sport">Australian Institute of Sport</a> in <a href="Canberra">Canberra</a> before taking his game to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> in December 2014 to play prep ball at <a href="La%20Lumiere%20School">La Lumiere School</a> in <a href="La%20Porte%2C%20Indiana">La Porte, Indiana</a>. Humphries enrolled at the <a href="Kentucky%20Wildcats%20men%27s%20basketball">University of Kentucky</a> in 2015 and saw action in 23 games as a freshman. Coming off the bench in all but one game, he averaged 1.9 points and 2.4 rebounds in 9.1 minutes per contest.
In the 2016–17 campaign, Humphries appeared in 38 games for the Wildcats with one start, producing averages of 2.8 points and 2.8 boards per outing in 8.3 minutes a game. He scored a career-high 12 points in his last college game, Kentucky’s 73-75 loss to the <a href="North%20Carolina%20Tar%20Heels%20men%27s%20basketball">North Carolina Tar Heels</a> in the South Region finals where he was also named in the NCAA All-Regional tournament team.
In April 2017, Humphries declared for the NBA draft, forgoing his final two years of college eligibility.
Professional career.
Sydney Kings (2017–2018).
Opting to turn professional, Humphries worked out with several NBA franchises over the summer, including the <a href="Washington%20Wizards">Washington Wizards</a>, after going undrafted in the <a href="2017%20NBA%20draft">2017 NBA draft</a>. Humphries returned to Australia and signed with his hometown team the <a href="Sydney%20Kings">Sydney Kings</a> on 27 July 2017 for the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20NBL%20season">2017–18 NBL season</a>. With the Kings, Humphries averaged 6.9 points, 3.6 rebounds and 1.0 blocks while shooting 58 percent in 16 minutes per game, making six starts in 26 appearances. He was subsequently named the <a href="NBL%20Rookie%20of%20the%20Year%20Award">NBL Rookie of the Year</a>.
FMP Beograd (2018).
On 27 February 2018, Humphries agreed to a deal with <a href="KK%20FMP%20Beograd">FMP</a> of the <a href="Basketball%20League%20of%20Serbia">Basketball League of Serbia</a>.
Erie BayHawks (2018–2019).
On 8 October 2018, Humphries signed a training camp deal with the <a href="Atlanta%20Hawks">Atlanta Hawks</a>, but was later waived the day after. Humphries was added to the training camp roster of the <a href="Erie%20BayHawks%20%282017%E2%80%93%29">Erie BayHawks</a> in October 2018.
Atlanta Hawks (2019).
On 1 April 2019, the <a href="Atlanta%20Hawks">Atlanta Hawks</a> announced they had signed Humphries for the remainder of 2018–19 season, after the end of the 2018/2019 season Humphries was waived by the Hawks.
Humphries joined the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Clippers">Los Angeles Clippers</a> for the <a href="2019%20NBA%20Summer%20League">2019 NBA Summer League</a> in <a href="Las%20Vegas">Las Vegas</a>.
Lakeland Magic (2019–2020).
On 24 September 2019, Humphries signed with the <a href="Orlando%20Magic">Orlando Magic</a>. He was waived and assigned to the <a href="Lakeland%20Magic">Lakeland Magic</a>. Humphries averaged 8.8 points, 5.9 rebounds, and 1.6 blocks per game during the 2019-20 season.
Adelaide 36ers (2020–2021).
On 16 July 2020, Humphries signed a two-year deal to return to the NBL with the <a href="Adelaide%2036ers">Adelaide 36ers</a>. He averaged 13.3 points, 7.1 rebounds, and a league-leading 2.8 blocks per game during the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20NBL%20season">2020–21 season</a>. His mutual option for a second season with the 36ers was not exercised.
On 9 July 2021, Humphries re-signed with the 36ers for the <a href="2021%E2%80%9322%20NBL%20season">2021–22 NBL season</a>.
National team career.
Humphries made his debut for the Australian junior national team at the 2013 <a href="FIBA%20Oceania%20Under-16%20Championship">FIBA Oceania Under-16 Championship</a>. In 2014, he helped Australia win the silver medal at the <a href="2014%20FIBA%20Under-17%20World%20Championship">FIBA Under-17 World Championship</a>, averaging 18.9 points, 11.6 rebounds and 3.3 blocks per game during the tournament. He was <a href="FIBA%20Under-17%20Basketball%20World%20Cup%20All-Tournament%20Team">named to the All-Tournament Team</a>. Humphries made his senior debut for the <a href="Australia%20national%20basketball%20team">Australian national team</a> in a <a href="2019%20FIBA%20Basketball%20World%20Cup">2019 FIBA World Cup</a> qualifying match against <a href="Kazakhstan%20national%20basketball%20team">Kazakhstan</a>, where he recorded 17 points and 7 rebounds in a dominant performance.
